text.sentence: Technology | U.S. Data Networking eleven February two thousand fifteen
Cisco's shares look compelling on a valuation basis ­ and investors seem to appreciate the capital return story and stability of EPS estimates.
While the highlight of the call was CEO John Chamber's bullish tone, we believe there could be some questions around the sub seasonal performance in switching off of a difficult compare.

That being said, better execution, a growing dividend and attractive valuation should support shares ­ though we would still like to see more evidence of a sustainable product cycle in switching beyond a few quarters.
Our annual estimates are essentially unchanged, and we maintain our price target of dollar twenty nine.
four Bn was also slightly above our estimate of dollar eleven.eight
Results were helped by y/y growth in core product sets which offset ongoing softness in carriers and emerging markets.

While demand in developed regions seems stable and new products have better momentum relative to several quarters ago, visibility into carrier and EM is still limited at this point, which is reflected in guidance.
Cisco expects FthreeQ revenues to be up three five percent y/y, implying a range of dollar eleven.eighty

We note that guidance implies a FthreeQ q/q growth of half a percent at the midpoint versus a historical average of +three percent ­ so investors will likely believe it seems conservative coming off a FtwoQ with a product book to bill above one.
Our estimates are essentially unchanged and balance improved trends in most developed markets as well as new product ramps offset by carrier and emerging market weakness.
For FYtwo thousand fifteen, we now estimate EPS of dollar two.sixteen based on three.seven
Bn and gross and operating margin of sixty two percent and twenty eight.four
Our two thousand fifteen estimates include FthreeQ EPS of dollar .fifty
two, which is based on revenue growth of five percent y/y to dollar twelve.seven
For FYtwo thousand sixteen we estimate EPS of dollar two.twenty five based on four percent y/y revenue growth to dollar fifty.eight

U.S. Data Networking Industry View: NEUTRAL Stock Rating: EQUAL WEIGHT two thousand fifteenE forty eight thousand eight hundred eighty two thirteen thousand eight hundred seventy four fourteen thousand two hundred sixty seven eleven thousand one hundred twenty nine two.sixteen five thousand one hundred forty seven.eight

five two thousand sixteenE fifty thousand eight hundred thirty three fourteen thousand two hundred seventy three fourteen thousand seven hundred thirteen eleven thousand four hundred seventy seven two.twenty five five thousand ninety two.five
six two thousand seventeenE fifty two thousand six hundred twenty nine fourteen thousand eight hundred seventy fifteen thousand three hundred ten eleven thousand nine hundred forty three two.thirty
Price USD twenty six.ninety three Price Target USD twenty nine.
We are EW on Cisco as we believe a mix of secular and macro headwinds and a lack of catalysts will keep the stock range bound over the next year.
Strong FCF yield, leading dividend yield and better execution warrant some modest multiple expansion but emerging market and service provider weakness will likely limit upside.
Accelerated new product traction, recapturing lost share, and margin improvements could yield an upside FYtwo thousand sixteen EPS of ~ dollar two.fifty.
Our upside case embeds a fourteenx multiple, which is slightly ahead of historical averages.
Ongoing product portfolio pressure, emerging market weakness, market share loss, and margin pressure could yield a downside FYsixteen EPS of ~ dollar two..

four Bn was also slightly above our estimate of dollar eleven.eight
Results were helped by y/y growth in core product sets ­ routing, switching, and servers ­ which offset ongoing softness in carriers and emerging markets .

While demand in developed regions seems stable and new products have better momentum relative to several quarters ago, visibility into carrier and EM is still limited at this point, which is reflected in guidance.
New CFO Kelly Kramer reiterated the company's capital allocation policy and cited it has been eighty six percent in the first two quarters of Cisco's FYfifteen.
The pace of buybacks was roughly consistent with levels from last quarter with repurchases of roughly dollar one.two
We believe the dollar one Bn quarterly run rate seems sustainable through FYfifteen.
Lastly, Cisco increased its dividend by two cents to dollar .twenty
From a geographic view, Americas' revenue was five percent q/q, +ten percent y/y, EMEA was +three percent q/q, +seven percent y/y, and APJC was flat q/q, three percent y/y.
The US grew seven percent in terms of orders ­ commercial was +twelve percent, enterprise was +three percent,, SP was down mid single digits, and Federal was +twenty three percent .
The company noted that the US enterprise order rate was slower than expected due to the timing of large deals and that the pipeline remains very healthy.
EMEA orders were +seven y/y helped by southern Europe, UK and Germany .
Emerging markets order trends turned positive following five consecutive quarters of decline.
Orders in the BRICs + Mexico were down six percent, with China declining nineteen percent .
Cisco will continue to operate under the assumption that emerging markets will remain challenging for at least several more quarters.
percent declined one hundred sixty bps from elevated levels last quarter but were within the company's long standing guidance range of sixty one sixty two percent .
The sequential decline was led by product margins which were sixty.eight
We believe the q/q fall off was largely the result of much better UCS results vs. our expectations ­ servers carry significantly lower margins that Cisco's corporate average.

While our checks continue to suggest aggressive pricing from Cisco ­ especially in the data center switching arena vs. Arista and white box ­ the company has noted that its new designs enable stable margin trends across its switching portfolio, including ACI related products.
The company seems to be executing on its strategy to layer more software and services on top of its equipment to keep margins in the target range.
Cisco's shares look compelling on a valuation basis ­ and investors seem to appreciate the capital return story and stability of EPS estimates.
While the highlight of the call was CEO John Chamber's bullish tone, we believe there could be some questions around the sub seasonal performance in switching off of a difficult compare.

That being said, better execution, a growing dividend and attractive valuation should support shares ­ though we would still like to see more evidence of a sustainable product cycle in switching beyond a few quarters.
Our annual estimates are essentially unchanged, and we maintain our price target of dollar twenty nine.
With respect to the outlook, Cisco expects revenues in the April quarter to be up three five percent y/y, implying a range of dollar eleven.eighty
Gross margins are expected to be sixty one sixty two percent and operating margins are expected to be twenty seven.five

Guidance implies a FthreeQ q/q growth of half a percent at the midpoint versus a historical average of +three percent ­ so investors will likely believe it seems conservative coming off a FtwoQ with a product book to bill above one.
Cisco's guidance continues to balance better trends in the enterprise within most developed
Barclays | Cisco Systems, Inc. regions with ongoing weakness in carrier and emerging markets ­ the two areas that have been ailing the company for multiple quarters.

Emerging markets seem to be getting better in most regions, though visibility into major countries like China, Russia and Brazil is still limited and weakness will likely persist for at least several more quarters.

While service provider seems to be bottoming, the company is not factoring in any improvement in the carrier spending environment and is operating under the assumption that global capex will be down mid single digits in Ctwo thousand fifteen.
In terms of segments, switching may have been roughly in line with consensus expectations but it was below our estimates, growing eleven percent y/y but declining six percent q/q.
The q/q decline was sharper than typical seasonal trends as the company cited a difficult comp ­ though we were expecting the company's product cycle to mute the effects of seasonality.
Cisco is not overly concerned, citing stronger order trends and y/y metrics .

The Nexus threeK and nineK switches collectively grew three hundred fifty percent y/y and the company noted that its nineK/ACI customer count climbed to one thousand seven hundred from roughly nine hundred seventy last quarter.
The APIC controller software seems to be gaining momentum as well and now has three hundred paying customers from one hundred sixty last quarter.
Routing sales were actually slightly better than subdued expectations as the company returned to positive growth following nine consecutive quarters of flat or declining revenue on a y/y basis.
Cisco noted good traction with its high end routing portfolio, which was up five percent on better trends with CRS X and NCS.
The company expects difficult conditions with respect to carrier spending given consolidation and uncertainty around net neutrality.

Servers were the real stand out in the quarter with revenue of roughly dollar eight hundred fifty Mn, well surpassing consensus expectations of dollar seven hundred forty Mn driven by cloud and big data applications in the enterprise.

Wireless also was able to maintain its improved trajectory, growing twenty percent y/y helped by continued momentum with Meraki which was up one hundred percent + and is now on an annualized run rate of dollar four hundred Mn.
We would note Cisco benefitted from a particularly easy comp in wireless this quarter as wireless revenue in FtwoQfourteen was five percent .
While trends for wireless seem intact within the enterprise, we believe a near term slowdown in education related to E rate will likely pose a headwind in ConeH.
Our estimates are essentially unchanged and balance improved trends in most developed markets as well as new product ramps offset by carrier and emerging market weakness.
For FYtwo thousand fifteen, we now estimate EPS of dollar two.sixteen based on three.seven
Bn and gross and operating margin of sixty two percent and twenty eight.four
Our two thousand fifteen estimates include FthreeQ EPS of dollar .fifty
two, which is based on revenue growth of five percent y/y to dollar twelve.seven
For FYtwo thousand sixteen we estimate EPS of dollar two.twenty five based on four percent y/y revenue growth to dollar fifty.eight
For FYtwo thousand seventeen, we estimate EPS of dollar two.thirty seven based on three.five
Our dollar twenty nine price target is based on thirteenx our FYtwo thousand sixteen EPS estimate of dollar two.twenty five.
We believe more stable trends, improved execution and a group leading relative dividend yield warrant a multiple in line with some of its large cap peers that face some similar secular challenges.

Guide to the Barclays Fundamental Equity Research Rating System: Our coverage analysts use a relative rating system in which they rate stocks as Overweight, Equal Weight or Underweight relative to other companies covered by the analyst or a team of analysts that are deemed to be in the same industry .
In addition to the stock rating, we provide industry views which rate the outlook for the industry coverage universe as Positive, Neutral or Negative .
A rating system using terms such as buy, hold and sell is not the equivalent of our rating system.
Investors should carefully read the entire research report including the definitions of all ratings and not infer its contents from ratings alone.
Stock Rating Overweight The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.
Equal Weight The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelvemonth investment horizon.
Underweight The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a twelve month investment horizon.

Rating Suspended The rating and target price have been suspended temporarily due to market events that made coverage impracticable or to comply with applicable regulations and/or firm policies in certain circumstances including where the Corporate and Investment Banking Division of Barclays is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or strategic transaction involving the company.
Neutral industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.

Below is the list of companies that constitute the industry coverage universe: U.S. Data Networking Arista Networks, Inc. Ffive Networks, Inc. Distribution of Ratings: Barclays Equity Research has two thousand six hundred eighty companies under coverage.

forty three percent have been assigned an Overweight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Buy rating; fifty six percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.

forty percent have been assigned an Equal Weight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Hold rating; forty six percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.

fourteen percent have been assigned an Underweight rating which, for purposes of mandatory regulatory disclosures, is classified as a Sell rating; forty three percent of companies with this rating are investment banking clients of the Firm.
Guide to the Barclays Research Price Target: Each analyst has a single price target on the stocks that they cover.
The price target represents that analyst's expectation of where the stock will trade in the next twelve months.
Upside/downside scenarios, where provided, represent potential upside/potential downside to each analyst's price target over the same twelve month period.
Top Picks: Barclays Equity Research's Top Picks represent the single best alpha generating investment idea within each industry, taken from among the Overweight rated stocks within that industry.
Barclays Equity Research publishes global and regional Top Picks reports every quarter and analysts may also publish intra quarter changes to their Top Picks, as necessary.
While analysts may highlight other Overweight rated stocks in their published research in addition to their Top Pick, there can only be one Top Pick for each industry.
The current list of Top Picks is available on https://live.barcap
dot com /go/RSL/servlets/dv.search?pubType=four thousand five hundred twenty six and amp;contentType=latest.

C: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate is a market maker and/or liquidity provider in equity securities issued by Cisco Systems, Inc. or one of its affiliates.
D: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received compensation for investment banking services from Cisco Systems, Inc. in the past twelve months.

J: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate trades regularly in the securities of Cisco Systems, Inc.. K: Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate has received non investment banking related compensation from Cisco Systems, Inc. within the past twelve months.
L: Cisco Systems, Inc. is, or during the past twelve months has been, an investment banking client of Barclays Bank PLC and/or an affiliate.

Valuation Methodology: Our dollar twenty nine price target reflects thirteenx our FYtwo thousand sixteen EPS estimate of dollar two.twenty five.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Price Target: Our forecasts assume Cisco can maintain its dominant market share position in the core enterprise market for networking equipment, all the while maintaining its industry leading operating margins.

Should weakness in enterprise IT spending demand persist beyond our current expectations; should the company cede significant market share to its competitors in coming quarters; or should the company's operating margins deteriorate considerably, we may consider revisiting our projections, investment rating and price target.

In addition, Cisco derives twenty twenty five percent of its sales from the service provider arena so should our outlook for global capital expenditures materially worsen, then our projections, investment rating and price target may need to be adjusted.
